prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference (2nd ed.)
prior_works.role: Foundational framework (SCMs and Pearl Causal Hierarchy)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s notion of L3-identifiability and its goal of answering all counterfactual queries consistently are grounded in Pearl’s SCM semantics and the Pearl Causal Hierarchy introduced and systematized in Causality.

prior_works.title: Identification of Conditional Interventional Distributions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By establishing complete identification procedures for interventional (L2) queries, this work provides the baseline that the paper explicitly seeks to extend via TM-SCMs toward the stronger model conditions required for L3-identifiability.

prior_works.title: Complete Identification of Counterfactuals
prior_works.role: Criteria and completeness for L3 (counterfactual) identification
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The target of complete counterfactual identifiability at level L3 and the associated logical/graphical machinery directly motivate the paper’s introduction of exogenous isomorphism as a sufficient model-identifiability notion to guarantee L3-identifiability.

prior_works.title: Transportability of Causal and Statistical Relations: A Formal Approach
prior_works.role: Conceptual and graphical basis for transportability
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s "counterfactual transport" intuition for Bijective SCMs builds on transportability—mapping causal knowledge across environments—providing the conceptual bridge to exogenous bijections that preserve answers to counterfactual queries.

prior_works.title: A Linear Non-Gaussian Acyclic Model for Causal Discovery (LiNGAM)
prior_works.authors: Shohei Shimizu, Patrik O. Hoyer, Aapo Hyvärinen, Antti Kerminen
prior_works.role: Triangular SCM structure and exogenous noise identifiability
prior_works.relationship_sentence: LiNGAM’s use of a triangular causal ordering with identifiable exogenous noises informs the paper’s TM-SCM class, illustrating how structural and monotonic constraints can deliver model-level identifiability beyond distributional equivalence.

prior_works.title: Nonlinear Causal Discovery with Additive Noise Models
prior_works.authors: Patrik O. Hoyer, Dominik Janzing, Joris M. Mooij, Jonas Peters, Bernhard Schölkopf
prior_works.role: Functional restrictions enabling identifiability via exogenous independence
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The ANM framework shows how functional/independence constraints on exogenous variables yield identifiability, directly inspiring the paper’s use of structural classes (TM-SCMs) to secure exogenous isomorphism and, hence, L3-identifiability.

prior_works.title: Characterization and Greedy Learning of Interventional Markov Equivalence Classes of Directed Acyclic Graphs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Results on interventional Markov equivalence clarify the limits of L2-identifiability, motivating the paper’s strengthening to exogenous isomorphism and its TM-SCM results that move beyond L2 to ensure consistency for all counterfactuals.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper advances complete counterfactual (L3) identifiability by introducing exogenous isomorphism as a model-level condition ensuring that all counterfactual queries agree across admissible SCMs. This agenda is anchored in Pearl’s SCM formalism and the Pearl Causal Hierarchy, which define what L3-identifiability entails. Foundational identification results at L2 (Shpitser & Pearl, 2006) and the completeness program for counterfactuals at L3 (Shpitser & Pearl, 2008) delineate the logical target: guaranteeing unique answers to all counterfactuals given assumptions. However, interventional equivalence results (Hauser & Bühlmann, 2012) reveal that many models remain indistinguishable at L2, highlighting the need for stronger structural constraints if one aims for L3 certainty.
To construct such constraints, the paper leverages two lines of work. First, transportability (Bareinboim & Pearl, 2013) provides the conceptual lens of transporting causal information across settings, which the authors specialize into “counterfactual transport” via bijections on exogenous variables in their Bijective SCMs. Second, identifiability from functional restrictions in triangular models—exemplified by LiNGAM (Shimizu et al., 2006) and nonlinear additive-noise models (Hoyer et al., 2009)—demonstrates how exogenous independence, triangularity, and monotonicity can lift model identifiability. Building on these insights, the paper defines exogenous isomorphism and derives sufficient conditions for EI-identifiability in Bijective SCMs and Triangular Monotonic SCMs. This unifies transport-based reasoning with structurally identifiable SCM classes, furnishing theory that bridges L2 methods and fully counterfactual-consistent inference and enabling practical neural TM-SCM implementations.
